Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story:
I sat in the cramped hotel room, my headset pressing into my ear as I dialed the next number on my list. The faint scent of incense from my suitcase mixed with the sterile air. I was hundreds of miles from home, here for the festival that my family had waited for all year. My mother’s voice echoed in my mind: “You must be present for every ritual, beta. The blessings are strongest when we are together.” But my manager’s email was clear—no missed calls, no excuses, even on the road.

The line connected. A customer’s angry voice burst through, demanding to know why our offer was legitimate, why he should trust me. I tried to steady my voice, recalling the training: stay calm, answer every objection, don’t let them hang up. But my phone buzzed with messages from my cousin: “The puja is starting. Where are you?” My heart pounded. I could almost hear the temple bells in the distance, the chanting, the swirl of marigold petals. I was expected to be fully present, to offer prayers with my family, but here I was, tethered to my script, my customer’s frustration growing. I felt torn, pulled by two worlds that refused to let go.
